awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Endoscopic Patient Mask to Limit Aerosolization During Endoscopic Procedures During COVID-19 Pandemic
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to help manage COVID-19 transmission in hospitals with a novel patient face mask to limit transmission of SARS-CoV-2 virus during endoscopic procedures.  All endoscopic procedures are considered aerosol-generating procedures because of the possibility of coughing and retching during upper endoscopy, and the passage of flatus during colonoscopy. The proposed patient endoscopic mask limit the spread of microdroplet and aerosols from the patient. This project proposes to develop an endoscopy mask which will be disposable, single use, with an oral opening for the introduction of an endoscope to the gastrointestinal tract. The proposed solution will allow most type of endoscopes, probes, and tubes to be inserted through the mask and enter the mouth or nose, while providing a seal between the mask and scope to limit leakage during the procedure. In addition, it will reduce the post-procedure wait time needed for air circulation in the endoscopy room to remove aerosols for the safety of patients and gastrointestinal health care givers. The solution will be useful for managing transmissions of any airborne infections.             

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will develop a novel technology that seals between the mask opening and an endoscope, while allowing the endoscope's advancement inside the gastrointestinal tract. The challenge with sealing the mask comes from the scope, which must have significant freedom of motion when it is inserted into the mouth of a patient. The proposed mask will have an access for suction to clear airway secretions and to remove aerosol and micro-droplets generated during endoscopic procedures. If successful, this seal technology can be utilized in other aerosol-generating clinical applications, such as reducing spread of aerosolized droplets of blood in laparoscopic surgery procedure.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
SARS-CoV-2/Novel Coronavirus-19 (COVID-19) has become a global pandemic. Human-to-human transmission occurs through respiratory secretions and aerosols. Transmission can occur in both symptomatic and asymptomatic individuals. Aerosol-generating medical procedures (AGMP)s carry a high risk of COVID-19 transmission. According to a joint American Gastroenterology Society statement, all endoscopic procedures should be considered aerosol-generating procedures owing to the possibility of coughing and retching during upper endoscopy and the passage of flatus during colonoscopy. This project is valuable and timely because it addresses an urgent clinical need to limit aerosolization during endoscopic procedures during the COVID-19 pandemic.

In Phase I Research, we demonstrated the feasibility of a novel patient face mask to limit aerosolization during endoscopic procedures. The mask is disposable, single use, with an oral opening for the introduction of an endoscope to the gastrointestinal tract via mouth. The technical innovation of the proposed mask utilizes a novel stackable seal, consisting of thin membranes which provide a seal between the mask opening and an endoscope while allowing the advancement of the endoscope inside gastrointestinal tract. The mask has an access for suction to clear airway secretions and to remove aerosol and micro droplets generated during endoscopic procedures.

In Phase I, we successfully designed, developed, and built a proof-of-concept endoscopic patient face mask prototype and tested the performance of the proposed novel seal technology. We validated the viability and scalability of design features for a commercialized product at a low cost. In addition, we performed customer discovery and continuous physicians feedback studies to verify the clinical needs, ease of use, and the impact of the mask on physician's technique to perform endoscopy.
